title: My Main Project
text:
I like to plot data.


I also analyze data.

title: A Replication of Karlan and List (2007)
text:
Dean Karlan at Yale and John List at the University of Chicago conducted a field experiment to test the effectiveness of different fundraising letters. They sent out 50,000 fundraising letters to potential donors, randomly assigning each letter to one of three treatments: a standard letter, a matching grant letter, or a challenge grant letter. They published the results of this experiment in the American Economic Review in 2007. The article and supporting data are available from the AEA website and from Innovations for Poverty Action as part of Harvard’s Dataverse.
to do: expand on the description of the experiment.
This project seeks to replicate their results.

title: A Replication of Karlan and List (2007)
text:
Dean Karlan at Yale and John List at the University of Chicago conducted a field experiment to test the effectiveness of different fundraising letters. They sent out 50,000 fundraising letters to potential donors, randomly assigning each letter to one of three treatments: a standard letter, a matching grant letter, or a challenge grant letter. They published the results of this experiment in the American Economic Review in 2007. The article and supporting data are available from the AEA website and from Innovations for Poverty Action as part of Harvard’s Dataverse.
to do: expand on the description of the experiment.
This project seeks to replicate their results.

title: A Replication of Karlan and List (2007)

Data

Variable Definitions

Description

Treatment


control
Control

Match threshold

$50,000 match threshold

$100,000 match threshold


sizeno
Unstated match threshold


ask
Suggested donation amount

Suggested donation was highest previous contribution


askd2
Suggested donation was 1.25 x highest previous contribution


askd3
Suggested donation was 1.50 x highest previous contribution

Highest previous contribution (for suggestion)

1.25 x highest previous contribution (for suggestion)

1.50 x highest previous contribution (for suggestion)

Dollars given

Change in amount given

Highest previous contribution

Small prior donor: last gift was less than median $35


freq
Number of prior donations


years
Number of years since initial donation


year5
At least 5 years since initial donation


mrm2
Number of months since last donation


dormant
Already donated in 2005


female
Female


couple
Couple


state50one
State tag: 1 for one observation of each of 50 states; 0 otherwise


nonlit
Nonlitigation


cases
Court cases from state in 2004-5 in which organization was involved


statecnt
Percent of sample from state


stateresponse
Proportion of sample from the state who gave


stateresponset
Proportion of treated sample from the state who gave


stateresponsec
Proportion of control sample from the state who gave


stateresponsetminc
stateresponset - stateresponsec

State vote share for Bush

State vote share for Bush between 47.5% and 52.5%

bluecty
Blue county

Proportion white within zip code

Average household size within zip code


median_hhincome
Median household income within zip code


powner
Proportion house owner within zip code


psch_atlstba
Proportion who finished college within zip code


pop_propurban
Proportion of population urban within zip code








Balance Test
As an ad hoc test of the randomization mechanism, I provide a series of tests that compare aspects of the treatment and control groups to assess whether they are statistically significantly different from one another.
todo: test a few variables other than the key outcome variables (for example, test months since last donation) to see if the treatment and control groups are statistically significantly different at the 95% confidence level. Do each as a t-test and separately as a linear regression, and confirm you get the exact same results from both methods. When doing a t-test, use the formula in the class slides. When doing the linear regression, regress for example mrm2 on treatment and look at the estimated coefficient on the treatment variable. It might be helpful to compare parts of your analysis to Table 1 in the paper. Be sure to comment on your results (hint: why is Table 1 included in the paper).

title: A Replication of Karlan and List (2007)
text:
Experimental Results

Charitable Contribution Made
First, I analyze whether matched donations lead to an increased response rate of making a donation.
todo: make a barplot with two bars. Each bar is the proportion of people who donated. One bar for treatment and one bar for control.
todo: run a t-test between the treatment and control groups on the binary outcome of whether any charitable donation was made. Also run a bivariate linear regression that demonstrates the same finding. (It may help to confirm your calculations match Table 2a Panel A.) Report your statistical results and interpret them in the context of the experiment (e.g., if you found a difference with a small p-value or that was statistically significant at some threshold, what have you learned about human behavior? Use mostly English words, not numbers or stats, to explain your finding.)
todo: run a probit regression where the outcome variable is whether any charitable donation was made and the explanatory variable is assignment to treatment or control. Confirm that your results replicate Table 3 column 1 in the paper.


Differences between Match Rates
Next, I assess the effectiveness of different sizes of matched donations on the response rate.
todo: Use a series of t-tests to test whether the size of the match ratio has an effect on whether people donate or not. For example, does the 2:1 match rate lead increase the likelihood that someone donates as compared to the 1:1 match rate? Do your results support the “figures suggest” comment the authors make on page 8?
todo: Assess the same issue using a regression. Specifically, create the variable ratio1 then regress gave on ratio1, ratio2, and ratio3 (or alternatively, regress gave on the categorical variable ratio). Interpret the coefficients and their statistical precision.
todo: Calculate the response rate difference between the 1:1 and 2:1 match ratios and the 2:1 and 3:1 ratios. Do this directly from the data, and do it by computing the differences in the fitted coefficients of the previous regression. what do you conclude regarding the effectiveness of different sizes of matched donations?


Size of Charitable Contribution
In this subsection, I analyze the effect of the size of matched donation on the size of the charitable contribution.
todo: Calculate a t-test or run a bivariate linear regression of the donation amount on the treatment status. What do we learn from doing this analysis?
todo: now limit the data to just people who made a donation and repeat the previous analysis. This regression allows you to analyze how much respondents donate conditional on donating some positive amount. Interpret the regression coefficients – what did we learn? Does the treatment coefficient have a causal interpretation?
todo: Make two plot: one for the treatment group and one for the control. Each plot should be a histogram of the donation amounts only among people who donated. Add a red vertical bar or some other annotation to indicate the sample average for each plot.

title: A Replication of Karlan and List (2007)
text:
Simulation Experiment
As a reminder of how the t-statistic “works,” in this section I use simulation to demonstrate the Law of Large Numbers and the Central Limit Theorem.
Suppose the true distribution of respondents who do not get a charitable donation match is Bernoulli with probability p=0.018 that a donation is made.
Further suppose that the true distribution of respondents who do get a charitable donation match of any size is Bernoulli with probability p=0.022 that a donation is made.

Law of Large Numbers
to do: Make a plot like those on slide 43 from our first class and explain the plot to the reader. To do this, you will simulate 100,00 draws from the control distribution and 10,000 draws from the treatment distribution. You’ll then calculate a vector of 10,000 differences, and then you’ll plot the cumulative average of that vector of differences. Comment on whether the cumulative average approaches the true difference in means.


Central Limit Theorem
to do: Make 4 histograms like those on slide 44 from our first class at sample sizes 50, 200, 500, and 1000 and explain these plots to the reader. To do this for a sample size of e.g. 50, take 50 draws from each of the control and treatment distributions, and calculate the average difference between those draws. Then repeat that process 999 more times so that you have 1000 averages. Plot the histogram of those averages. Comment on whether zero is in the “middle” of the distribution or whether it’s in the “tail.”

title: A Replication of Karlan and List (2007)
text:
Dean Karlan at Yale and John List at the University of Chicago conducted a field experiment to test the effectiveness of different fundraising letters. They sent out 50,000 fundraising letters to potential donors, randomly assigning each letter to one of three treatments: a standard letter, a matching grant letter, or a challenge grant letter. They published the results of this experiment in the American Economic Review in 2007. The article and supporting data are available from the AEA website and from Innovations for Poverty Action as part of Harvard’s Dataverse.
to do: expand on the description of the experiment.
This project seeks to replicate their results.

Balance Test
As an ad hoc test of the randomization mechanism, I provide a series of tests that compare aspects of the treatment and control groups to assess whether they are statistically significantly different from one another.
todo: test a few variables other than the key outcome variables (for example, test months since last donation) to see if the treatment and control groups are statistically significantly different at the 95% confidence level. Do each as a t-test and separately as a linear regression, and confirm you get the exact same results from both methods. When doing a t-test, use the formula in the class slides. When doing the linear regression, regress for example mrm2 on treatment and look at the estimated coefficient on the treatment variable. It might be helpful to compare parts of your analysis to Table 1 in the paper. Be sure to comment on your results (hint: why is Table 1 included in the paper).

# Drop the missing value

karlan_list_cleaned = karlan_list.dropna(subset=['mrm2'])

# Separating the groups

control = karlan_list_cleaned[karlan_list_cleaned['control'] == 1]['mrm2']

treatment = karlan_list_cleaned[karlan_list_cleaned['treatment'] == 1]['mrm2']

# T-test
t_stat, p_value = stats.ttest_ind(control, treatment, equal_var = False)

# Linear Regression
X = sm.add_constant(karlan_list_cleaned['treatment'])
y = karlan_list_cleaned['mrm2']
model = sm.OLS(y, X).fit()
summary = model.summary()

# Output
print(f"T-test Statistics: {t_stat}, P-value: {p_value}")

print(summary)

title: A Replication of Karlan and List (2007)
text:
Experimental Results

Charitable Contribution Made
First, I analyze whether matched donations lead to an increased response rate of making a donation.
todo: make a barplot with two bars. Each bar is the proportion of people who donated. One bar for treatment and one bar for control.

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Calculating the proportion for 'gave'

control_proportion = karlan_list[karlan_list['control'] == 1]['gave'].mean()

treatment_proportion = karlan_list[karlan_list['treatment'] == 1]['gave'].mean()

# Values for plotting
proportions = [control_proportion, treatment_proportion]
group_labels = ['Control', 'Treatment']

# Creating a bar plot
plt.figure(figsize = (8, 6))
plt.bar(group_labels, proportions, color = ['blue', 'red'])

# Set y-axis limits and ticks for better visibility if proportions are low
max_proportion = max(proportions)
plt.ylim(0, max_proportion * 1.2)  # Extend y-axis a bit above the max value for visual comfort
plt.yticks(np.arange(0, max_proportion * 1.2, step=max_proportion / 5))


# Adding labels and title
plt.ylabel('Proportion Who Donated')
plt.title('Proportion of Donations by Group')

# Display the plot
plt.show()








todo: run a t-test between the treatment and control groups on the binary outcome of whether any charitable donation was made. Also run a bivariate linear regression that demonstrates the same finding. (It may help to confirm your calculations match Table 2a Panel A.) Report your statistical results and interpret them in the context of the experiment (e.g., if you found a difference with a small p-value or that was statistically significant at some threshold, what have you learned about human behavior? Use mostly English words, not numbers or stats, to explain your finding.)

# Running a T-test
control_donations = karlan_list[karlan_list['control'] == 1]['gave']
treatment_donations = karlan_list[karlan_list['treatment'] == 1]['gave']

t_stat, p_value = stats.ttest_ind(control_donations, treatment_donations, equal_var = False)

# Running a Bivariate Linear Regression
X = sm.add_constant(karlan_list['treatment'])
y = karlan_list['gave']

model = sm.OLS(y, X).fit()
summary = model.summary()

# Output of T-test
print(f"T-test statistic: {t_stat}, P-value: {p_value}\n")

# Output of regression result
print(summary)

todo: run a probit regression where the outcome variable is whether any charitable donation was made and the explanatory variable is assignment to treatment or control. Confirm that your results replicate Table 3 column 1 in the paper.

# Preparing data for Probit Regression
X = sm.add_constant(karlan_list['treatment'])
y = karlan_list['gave']

# Initialize and fit the Probit model
probit_model = sm.Probit(y, X).fit()

coef = probit_model.params['treatment']
p_value = probit_model.pvalues['treatment']

print(probit_model.summary)
print('coef: ', coef)
print('p_value: ', p_value)

coef:  0.08678462244746639
p_value:  0.0018523990147768265




Differences between Match Rates
Next, I assess the effectiveness of different sizes of matched donations on the response rate.
todo: Use a series of t-tests to test whether the size of the match ratio has an effect on whether people donate or not. For example, does the 2:1 match rate lead increase the likelihood that someone donates as compared to the 1:1 match rate? Do your results support the “figures suggest” comment the authors make on page 8?

# T-test between 1:1 match rate and 2:1 match rate
gave_ratio1 = karlan_list[karlan_list['ratio'] == 1]['gave']
gave_ratio2 = karlan_list[karlan_list['ratio2'] == 1]['gave']
t_stat_1_vs_2, p_value_1_vs_2 = stats.ttest_ind(gave_ratio1, gave_ratio2, equal_var=False)

# T-test between 1:1 match rate and 3:1 match rate
gave_ratio3 = karlan_list[karlan_list['ratio3'] == 1]['gave']
t_stat_1_vs_3, p_value_1_vs_3 = stats.ttest_ind(gave_ratio1, gave_ratio3, equal_var=False)

# T-test between 2:1 match rate and 3:1 match rate
t_stat_2_vs_3, p_value_2_vs_3 = stats.ttest_ind(gave_ratio2, gave_ratio3, equal_var=False)

# Output the results
print(f"1:1 vs 2:1 T-test statistic: {t_stat_1_vs_2}, P-value: {p_value_1_vs_2}")
print(f"1:1 vs 3:1 T-test statistic: {t_stat_1_vs_3}, P-value: {p_value_1_vs_3}")
print(f"2:1 vs 3:1 T-test statistic: {t_stat_2_vs_3}, P-value: {p_value_2_vs_3}")

1:1 vs 2:1 T-test statistic: -0.965048975142932, P-value: 0.33453078237183076
1:1 vs 3:1 T-test statistic: -1.0150174470156275, P-value: 0.31010856527625774
2:1 vs 3:1 T-test statistic: -0.05011581369764474, P-value: 0.9600305476940865


todo: Assess the same issue using a regression. Specifically, create the variable ratio1 then regress gave on ratio1, ratio2, and ratio3 (or alternatively, regress gave on the categorical variable ratio). Interpret the coefficients and their statistical precision.
todo: Calculate the response rate difference between the 1:1 and 2:1 match ratios and the 2:1 and 3:1 ratios. Do this directly from the data, and do it by computing the differences in the fitted coefficients of the previous regression. what do you conclude regarding the effectiveness of different sizes of matched donations?


Size of Charitable Contribution
In this subsection, I analyze the effect of the size of matched donation on the size of the charitable contribution.
todo: Calculate a t-test or run a bivariate linear regression of the donation amount on the treatment status. What do we learn from doing this analysis?

# T-test on the amount donated between control and treatment groups
amount_control = karlan_list[karlan_list['control'] == 1]['amount']
amount_treatment = karlan_list[karlan_list['treatment'] == 1]['amount']
t_stat, p_value = stats.ttest_ind(amount_control, amount_treatment, equal_var=False)

# Bivariate Linear Regression of amount on treatment status
X = sm.add_constant(karlan_list['treatment'])
y = karlan_list['amount']
model = sm.OLS(y, X).fit()

# Print the t-test results
print(f"T-test statistic: {t_stat}, P-value: {p_value}")

print(model.summary())

todo: now limit the data to just people who made a donation and repeat the previous analysis. This regression allows you to analyze how much respondents donate conditional on donating some positive amount. Interpret the regression coefficients – what did we learn? Does the treatment coefficient have a causal interpretation?

# Filter the data to only include individuals who made a donation
donors = karlan_list[karlan_list['amount'] > 0]

# Perform a T-test on the donation amount between the control and treatment groups within donors
amount_control = donors[donors['control'] == 1]['amount']
amount_treatment = donors[donors['treatment'] == 1]['amount']
t_stat, p_value = stats.ttest_ind(amount_control, amount_treatment, equal_var=False)

# Print the t-test results for donors
print(f"T-test statistic for donors: {t_stat}, P-value for donors: {p_value}")

# Perform a Bivariate Linear Regression of donation amount on treatment status for donors
X_donors = sm.add_constant(donors['treatment'])  # Add a constant for the intercept
y_donors = donors['amount']
amount_model_donors = sm.OLS(y_donors, X_donors).fit()

# Print the summary of the regression model for donors
print(amount_model_donors.summary())

todo: Make two plot: one for the treatment group and one for the control. Each plot should be a histogram of the donation amounts only among people who donated. Add a red vertical bar or some other annotation to indicate the sample average for each plot.

# Separate the donors into treatment and control groups
treatment_donors = donors[donors['treatment'] == 1]
control_donors = donors[donors['control'] == 1]

# Calculate the sample averages for the treatment and control groups
avg_treatment_donation = treatment_donors['amount'].mean()
avg_control_donation = control_donors['amount'].mean()

# Plot histograms
fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(14, 7))

# Treatment group histogram
ax[0].hist(treatment_donors['amount'], bins=30, color='blue', alpha=0.7)
ax[0].axvline(avg_treatment_donation, color='red', linestyle='dashed', linewidth=2)
ax[0].set_title('Treatment Group Donation Amounts')
ax[0].set_xlabel('Donation Amount')
ax[0].set_ylabel('Frequency')
ax[0].annotate(f'Average: ${avg_treatment_donation:.2f}', 
               xy=(avg_treatment_donation, 5), 
               xytext=(avg_treatment_donation * 1.1, 25),
               arrowprops=dict(facecolor='red', shrink=0.05))

# Control group histogram
ax[1].hist(control_donors['amount'], bins=30, color='green', alpha=0.7)
ax[1].axvline(avg_control_donation, color='red', linestyle='dashed', linewidth=2)
ax[1].set_title('Control Group Donation Amounts')
ax[1].set_xlabel('Donation Amount')
ax[1].set_ylabel('Frequency')
ax[1].annotate(f'Average: ${avg_control_donation:.2f}', 
               xy=(avg_control_donation, 5), 
               xytext=(avg_control_donation * 1.1, 25),
               arrowprops=dict(facecolor='red', shrink=0.05))

# Show the plot
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

title: A Replication of Karlan and List (2007)
text:
Simulation Experiment
As a reminder of how the t-statistic “works,” in this section I use simulation to demonstrate the Law of Large Numbers and the Central Limit Theorem.
Suppose the true distribution of respondents who do not get a charitable donation match is Bernoulli with probability p=0.018 that a donation is made.
Further suppose that the true distribution of respondents who do get a charitable donation match of any size is Bernoulli with probability p=0.022 that a donation is made.

Law of Large Numbers
to do: Make a plot like those on slide 43 from our first class and explain the plot to the reader. To do this, you will simulate 100,00 draws from the control distribution and 10,000 draws from the treatment distribution. You’ll then calculate a vector of 10,000 differences, and then you’ll plot the cumulative average of that vector of differences. Comment on whether the cumulative average approaches the true difference in means.

import numpy as np

# Set seed for reproducibility
np.random.seed(0)

# Simulate draws for the control group and calculate the cumulative average
control_draws = np.random.choice(control_donors['amount'], size=100000, replace=True)
control_cumulative_avg = np.cumsum(control_draws) / np.arange(1, 100001)

# Simulate draws for the treatment group and calculate the cumulative average
treatment_draws = np.random.choice(treatment_donors['amount'], size=10000, replace=True)
treatment_cumulative_avg = np.cumsum(treatment_draws) / np.arange(1, 10001)

# Calculate the cumulative difference in means
cumulative_diff_means = treatment_cumulative_avg[:10000] - control_cumulative_avg[:10000]

# Plot the cumulative difference in means
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 6))
plt.plot(cumulative_diff_means, color='orange', lw=2)
plt.axhline(y=avg_treatment_donation - avg_control_donation, color='red', linestyle='--', linewidth=1.5)
plt.xlabel('Number of Draws')
plt.ylabel('Cumulative Difference in Means')
plt.title('Convergence of Cumulative Difference in Means Between Treatment and Control')
plt.show()










Central Limit Theorem
to do: Make 4 histograms like those on slide 44 from our first class at sample sizes 50, 200, 500, and 1000 and explain these plots to the reader. To do this for a sample size of e.g. 50, take 50 draws from each of the control and treatment distributions, and calculate the average difference between those draws. Then repeat that process 999 more times so that you have 1000 averages. Plot the histogram of those averages. Comment on whether zero is in the “middle” of the distribution or whether it’s in the “tail.”

# Set a seed for reproducibility
np.random.seed(0)

# Assume we have the control and treatment amounts as numpy arrays
control_amounts = karlan_list[karlan_list['control'] == 1]['amount'].values
treatment_amounts = karlan_list[karlan_list['treatment'] == 1]['amount'].values

sample_sizes = [50, 200, 500, 1000]
simulations = 1000

# Initialize a plot
fig, axs = plt.subplots(2, 2, figsize=(14, 10))
axs = axs.flatten()  # Flatten the array of axes for easy iteration

# True mean difference between treatment and control
true_diff = np.mean(treatment_amounts) - np.mean(control_amounts)

# Iterate over different sample sizes
for i, sample_size in enumerate(sample_sizes):
    # Store the average differences
    avg_diffs = []
    
    for _ in range(simulations):
        # Draw random samples from control and treatment
        control_sample = np.random.choice(control_amounts, sample_size, replace=True)
        treatment_sample = np.random.choice(treatment_amounts, sample_size, replace=True)
        
        # Calculate the average difference for this simulation
        avg_diff = np.mean(treatment_sample) - np.mean(control_sample)
        avg_diffs.append(avg_diff)
    
    # Plot the histogram of average differences for this sample size
    axs[i].hist(avg_diffs, bins=30, color='skyblue', edgecolor='black')
    axs[i].axvline(true_diff, color='red', linestyle='dashed', linewidth=2)
    axs[i].set_title(f'Sample Size: {sample_size}')
    axs[i].set_xlabel('Average Difference in Donation Amount')
    axs[i].set_ylabel('Frequency')

# Add a main title and adjust layout
plt.suptitle('Histograms of Average Differences Between Treatment and Control')
plt.tight_layout(rect=[0, 0.03, 1, 0.95])  # Adjust the rectangle to prevent overlap of the main title
plt.show()
